claim: James Watson and Gerald Edelman are people born in the United States who won a Nobel Prize for Physiology.

supporting.text: James Watson was born in Chicago, Illinois, USA, in 1928 and won the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 1962 for the discovery of the structure of DNA.

attacks.text: James Watson was born in Chicago, Illinois, USA, in 1928 and won the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 1962 for the discovery of the structure of DNA.
The claim mentions Gerald Edelman, but A1 only addresses James Watson, leaving half the claim unverified.
Gerald Edelman was born in New York City, USA, in 1929 and won the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 1972 for discoveries concerning the chemical structure of antibodies.

supporting.text: Gerald Edelman was born in New York City, USA, in 1929 and won the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 1972 for his work on the immune system.

attacks.text: Gerald Edelman was born in New York City, USA, in 1929 and won the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 1972 for his work on the immune system.
Gerald Edelman's Nobel Prize was shared with Rodney Porter, who was not born in the United States, which partially contradicts the claim's focus on individuals born in the US.
The claim specifies 'people born in the United States who won a Nobel Prize,' and Edelman qualifies as one such person, regardless of whether the prize was shared with a non-US-born individual.
The claim mentions James Watson, but A2 only provides evidence for Gerald Edelman, leaving Watson's birthplace and Nobel Prize unverified.
James Watson was indeed born in Chicago, USA, and won the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 1962, which supports the full claim alongside Edelman's case.

supporting.text: Both James Watson and Gerald Edelman are listed as American laureates in the official records of the Nobel Prize, confirming their US citizenship at the time of the award.

attacks.text: Both James Watson and Gerald Edelman are listed as American laureates in the official records of the Nobel Prize, confirming their US citizenship at the time of the award.
James Watson was born in Chicago, USA, but Gerald Edelman was born in New York City, USA, which is already known and does not require confirmation from Nobel Prize records.
The Nobel Prize records may not always accurately reflect the laureate's citizenship at birth, only their affiliation at the time of the award.
Historical records and birth certificates confirm both Watson and Edelman were born in the US, making the Nobel Prize records redundant for this claim.

supporting.text: The Nobel Prize organization's biographical notes for Watson and Edelman explicitly state their birthplaces as the United States, aligning with the claim.

attacks.text: The Nobel Prize organization's biographical notes for Watson and Edelman explicitly state their birthplaces as the United States, aligning with the claim.
The Nobel Prize organization's biographical notes may contain errors or outdated information regarding birthplaces.
Some Nobel laureates have dual citizenship, and their birthplace might not reflect their primary nationality at the time of the award.
Independent historical records and birth certificates confirm the birthplaces of Watson and Edelman as the United States, supporting the Nobel Prize organization's notes.

supporting.text: Historical records and reputable biographies consistently document Watson and Edelman as American scientists who made groundbreaking contributions to physiology, earning them the Nobel Prize.

attacks.text: Historical records and reputable biographies consistently document Watson and Edelman as American scientists who made groundbreaking contributions to physiology, earning them the Nobel Prize.
James Watson was born in Chicago, Illinois, which is in the United States, but Gerald Edelman was born in New York City, which is also in the United States, so the claim holds.
While Watson and Edelman were indeed born in the United States, the Nobel Prize is awarded for specific discoveries, not just contributions to physiology in general.

The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine was awarded to Watson for the discovery of the structure of DNA, and to Edelman for his work on the immune system, both of which are specific discoveries within physiology.
